claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination broadens interferon signaling and antigen processing to sensitize tumors.

evidence.quote: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
Interferon-associated antigen processing and presentation pathways increase.

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.

claims.claim: Combining the mRNA vaccine with anti-PD-L1 therapy improves tumor control in mice and mirrors better retrospective human outcomes.

evidence.quote: PD-L1 pathway activity also increases, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.
Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: Human survival data come from a retrospective, non-randomized cohort subject to confounding and heterogeneity.

claims.claim: Prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination was associated with improved survival among metastatic patients receiving ICI.

evidence.quote: Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.
Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment.

claims.caveat: Retrospective design, variable vaccination timing, and patient heterogeneity limit causal interpretation of the human survival association.

claims.claim: Mechanistic probes including IFNAR1 blockade showed the sensitization benefit depends on type I interferon signaling.

evidence.quote: Mechanistic probes: immunopeptidomics, transcriptomics, and perturbation controls (including IFNAR1 blockade and non-mRNA particle controls).
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: Mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
